verses.text: Zedekiah son of Josiah became king in place of Coniah son of Jehoiakim, whom Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon appointed as king over the land of Judah.
verses.comment: Zedekiah’s appointment by a foreign king demonstrates Judah’s subjection and the loss of true independence—a foreshadowing of spiritual exile when earthly powers rule God’s people instead of obedience to divine authority.

verses.text: But neither he nor his servants nor the people of the land listened to the words of the LORD spoken by the prophet Jeremiah.
verses.comment: Disobedience to God’s word leads to spiritual and national ruin, highlighting the necessity of submitting to authentic prophetic teaching. This principle echoes in Christ’s warnings about rejecting the truth (see Matt. 23:37).

verses.text: Yet King Zedekiah sent Jehucal son of Shelemiah and Zephaniah son of Maaseiah, the priest, to the prophet Jeremiah, saying, "Please pray to the LORD our God for us."
verses.comment: Zedekiah’s request for intercession, even while refusing obedience, reflects an appeal to mediation—a theme fulfilled perfectly in the New Covenant through Christ as our High Priest (Heb. 7:25).

verses.text: Now Jeremiah was still moving freely among the people, for he had not yet been put in prison.
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s freedom precedes his suffering, paralleling the prophets and Christ Himself, who taught openly before enduring persecution—the suffering of the righteous for the sake of God’s message.

verses.text: The army of Pharaoh had come out of Egypt. When the Chaldeans who were besieging Jerusalem heard news about them, they withdrew from Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Egypt’s intervention provides momentary relief but ultimately fails. Dependence on human alliances, rather than on God, is repeatedly shown to be futile—a spiritual lesson about the need for true faith.

verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah the prophet:
verses.comment: God speaks directly to His prophet, reinforcing the pattern of divine revelation through chosen vessels—a forerunner of apostolic teaching authority.

verses.text: The LORD said, "This is what you shall say to the king of Judah, who sent you to inquire of me: 'Pharaoh's army, which came to help you, is going to return to its own land, to Egypt.'"
verses.comment: The prophecy exposes the unreliability of Egypt and false hopes, further emphasizing God’s sovereignty over nations and His ultimate plan for salvation history.

verses.text: "The Chaldeans will return and fight against this city. They will capture it and burn it with fire."
verses.comment: Judgment is affirmed—Jerusalem will be destroyed. The city’s destruction prefigures the consequences of rejecting divine guidance and of spiritual pride (Luke 19:41–44).

verses.text: "Do not deceive yourselves, saying, ‘The Chaldeans will surely leave us,’ for they will not leave."
verses.comment: God warns against false hope and self-deception, underscoring the importance of trusting only in His promises—a caution often echoed by Christ against false teachers.

verses.text: "Even if you were to defeat the entire army of the Chaldeans fighting against you, and only wounded men remained, they would rise up each in his tent and burn this city with fire."
verses.comment: The inevitability of God’s judgment highlights His authority and the consequences for persistent unrepentance—reminding believers of the call to true conversion.

verses.text: Now when the Chaldean army had withdrawn from Jerusalem because of Pharaoh's army,
verses.comment: The temporary withdrawal seems to offer hope but is revealed to be a fleeting reprieve—true deliverance cannot rely on worldly strategies.

verses.text: Jeremiah set out from Jerusalem to go to the land of Benjamin to receive his portion there among the people.
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s return to his homeland for personal matters, even as a prophet, underscores the unity of spiritual duty and practical life—a holistic approach to vocation.

verses.text: While he was at the Gate of Benjamin, a captain of the guard named Irijah son of Shelemiah, son of Hananiah, seized Jeremiah the prophet, saying, "You are deserting to the Chaldeans!"
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s unjust accusation mirrors the suffering of the righteous, foreshadowing Christ’s betrayal and wrongful arrest (Mark 14:43–46).

verses.text: Jeremiah said, "It is a lie! I am not deserting to the Chaldeans." But Irijah would not listen to him; he arrested Jeremiah and brought him to the officials.
verses.comment: Like many prophets and even Jesus, Jeremiah is falsely accused and rejected by the leaders, teaching perseverance despite misunderstanding.

verses.text: The officials were angry with Jeremiah and beat him, and they put him in prison in the house of Jonathan the scribe, which they had made into a dungeon.
verses.comment: Suffering unjustly for the truth is a hallmark of authentic prophets and prefigures the suffering of Christ and the saints for righteousness.

verses.text: Jeremiah was put into a vaulted cell, where he remained for many days.
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s imprisonment shows both the isolation and endurance required of those faithful to God—a spiritual lesson for perseverance in trial.

verses.text: King Zedekiah sent for him and had him brought to his house. He secretly asked him, "Is there any word from the LORD?" Jeremiah answered, "There is." Then he said, "You shall be handed over to the king of Babylon."
verses.comment: The king’s secret inquiry reveals his troubled conscience. Jeremiah’s unwavering proclamation shows devotion to truth, even under pressure—a mark of true prophetic authority.

verses.text: Then Jeremiah said to King Zedekiah, "What crime have I committed against you, against your officials, or against this people, that you have put me in prison?
verses.comment: The innocence of Jeremiah underlines the wrongfulness of the persecution faced by those who faithfully speak God’s word—a reminder of Jesus’s own innocence in the face of condemnation.

verses.text: Where are your prophets who prophesied to you, saying, ‘The king of Babylon will not come against you or against this land?’"
verses.comment: Jeremiah exposes the false prophets. Discernment between true and false teachings remains essential, especially when contrasted with authentic apostolic succession and authority.

verses.text: But now, please listen, my lord the king. Let my plea come before you: Do not send me back to the house of Jonathan the scribe, lest I die there."
verses.comment: Jeremiah humbly petitions for mercy, showing that intercession and perseverance in suffering are spiritual practices, echoing the necessity of prayer for the living and the enduring witness of God’s servants.

verses.text: So King Zedekiah gave orders for Jeremiah to be committed to the courtyard of the guard and given a daily loaf of bread from the bakers’ street, until all the bread in the city was gone. So Jeremiah remained in the courtyard of the guard.
verses.comment: Though persecuted, Jeremiah receives sustenance, pointing to God’s providence for those who remain faithful. Daily bread echoes spiritual sustenance, reminding us of Christ’s care for His disciples (Matt. 6:11).
